docs.lead_paragraph: With Federal marshals posted outside and protesters waving pictures of aborted fetuses from the sidewalk, the clinic where Dr. Barnett A. Slepian performed abortions until he was slain on Friday night reopened here today and its director vowed to continue his work. Short-staffed even before Dr. Slepian was fatally shot by a sniper who hid in a wooded field behind his home, the clinic, Buffalo Women's Gynecological Services, scrambled to find doctors to cover his schedule.

headline.main: Abortion Clinic in Buffalo Vows To Continue Slain Doctor's Work

docs.abstract: Buffalo Women's Gynecological Services, clinic where Dr Barnett A Slepian performed abortions until he was slain, reopens with Federal marshals posted outside and protestors congregating across street; clinic's director, Marilynn Buckham, vows to continue Dr Slepian's work; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Alan Dickison went to the funeral of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian this afternoon carrying his two towheaded children, Connor, 4, and Kelsey, 2, a boy and girl whom Dr. Slepian had delivered. ''This man was about children,'' he said, brandishing the two children toward a cluster of reporters. ''This man was not about abortions.''

headline.main: Slain Physician Eulogized as Caring Man

docs.abstract: Funeral service held, Amherst, NY, for Dr Barnett A Slepian; FBI announces $100,000 reward it its investigation of slaying and abortion clinic where he worked vows to be opened for business this week; reaction of Amherst resident to slaying and to Dr Slepian's medical practice noted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Few pregnant women escape the well-meaning chums who insist they can tell a baby's sex from various telltale signs -- like the height of the mother's belly or the foods she craves. And those pals are right -- about half the time anyway.

headline.main: When Girls Make Their Mothers Sick

docs.abstract: British doctors report that male and female fetuses can affect mothers differently; find that asthmatics carrying girls are more likely to find symptoms worsen (S)
docs.snippet: Few pregnant women escape the well-meaning chums who insist they can tell a baby's sex from various telltale signs -- like the height of the mother's belly or the foods she craves.    And those pals are right -- about half the time anyway.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first commandment for couples wanting to adopt babies is: Put yourselves across. And they do, in spunky performances on videotapes, in lush scrapbooks and in professional portraiture smiling on the Internet. Many speak on the Web pages that crowd electronic registries of ''waiting families.'' Gloyd and Penny, for example, say, ''We pray daily for our birth mother and baby -- whoever and wherever they are.'' David and Paula promise, ''This child will be overwhelmed by love and affection.'' Rex and Carol wait, after 14 years of marriage, with a spaniel named Brittney and a vacation home four miles from Disney World.

headline.main: Market Puts Price Tags on the Priceless

docs.abstract: Second of three articles in series In Search of a Child: The Baby Bazaar; focuses on competition among infertile couples for smaller and smaller supply of white American-born infants; experts say imbalance between demand and supply allows money to play defining role, with couples spending average of $15,000 to $20,000 and some paying up to $100,000 to adopt newborn; sales of babies are illegal, but thousands of intermediaries sell access to young women who might relinquish babies, leaving only thinnest line between buying child and buying adoption services that lead to baby; table of payments permitted in various states; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The first commandment for couples wanting to adopt babies is: Put yourselves across. And they do, in spunky performances on videotapes, in lush scrapbooks and in professional portraiture smiling on the Internet.    Many speak on the Web pages that...

docs.lead_paragraph: Patty Murray swept into the United States Senate in 1992's ''Year of the Woman'' in the wake of national outrage over the all-male Senate Judiciary Committee's handling of sexual harassment accusations against a Supreme Court nominee. Six years later, in Ms. Murray's campaign, a woman is once again standing up for feminist values on the campaign trail -- ''fighting against leches in the workplace who hit on young women,'' as she puts it. But the candidate saying these things is not Senator Murray, a Democrat, who says she must remain an ''impartial juror'' in case President Clinton is impeached. Instead, it is her conservative Republican opponent, Representative Linda Smith, whose ire is on high alert. ''The feminist movement,'' Ms. Smith says, ''needs to stand up against any man who would use women like pieces of meat like our President has.''

headline.main: Democrat or Republican, Woman Will Be Winner

docs.abstract: Senate race in Washington between Patty Murray, incumbent Democrat, and Rep Linda Smith, conservative Republican, shows women's increasing political prominence and reflects rise in number of female Republican candidates; Murray and Smith, despite ideological differences, share many career similarities; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Patty Murray swept into the United States Senate in 1992's ''Year of the Woman'' in the wake of national outrage over the all-male Senate Judiciary Committee's handling of sexual harassment accusations against a Supreme Court nominee. Six years...

docs.lead_paragraph: With no arrests reported in Friday night's slaying of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian, the two doctors in the Buffalo area who publicly acknowledge performing abortions remained in seclusion today as residents of this picturesque Buffalo suburb struggled to grasp the thought of a sniper attack in their midst. Law enforcement officials from Federal, state and local agencies who met with Canadian investigators here today would not comment on their inquiry into the death of Dr. Slepian, who was killed by a sniper as he stood in his kitchen.

headline.main: Quiet, Affluent Town Is Stunned by Sniper Slaying of One of Its Doctors

docs.abstract: Two doctors in Buffalo area who publicly acknowledge performing abortions remain in seclusion in wake of Oct 23 murder of Dr Barnett A Slepian in his home in Amherst; Amherst struggles to grasp the thought of a sniper attack in their community; law enforcement authorities, following meeting with Canadian investigators, refuse to comment on their inquiry into slaying of Dr Slepian; abortion rights advocates say that clinics in area that perform abortions have been promised stepped-up security by law enforcement officials and will continue to operate normally (M)
docs.snippet: With no arrests reported in Friday night's slaying of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian, the two doctors in the Buffalo area who publicly acknowledge performing abortions remained in seclusion today as residents of this picturesque Buffalo suburb struggled to...

docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is not about soccer moms cheering from the sidelines, piling little tykes in cleats and shinguards into the backs of minivans and admonishing them not to get mud on the upholstery. It's not about carpooling from soccer game to drum practice to tennis lessons on Saturday afternoon and then shuttling back to soccer practice on Sunday. This is about soccer moms playing soccer.

headline.main: This Brand of Soccer Mom Wears Cleats

docs.abstract: Article on mothers on Long Island who belong to Long Island Ladies Soccer League, which has 51 teams; players and their children comment; village of Great Neck, NY, becomes first Long Island municipality to offer valet parking at public garage; photos (M)
docs.snippet: THIS is not about soccer moms cheering from the sidelines, piling little tykes in cleats and shinguards into the backs of minivans and admonishing them not to get mud on the upholstery. It's not about carpooling from soccer game to drum practice to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Yvette Weilacker sits in the kitchen of a small house in Buffalo waiting for the contractions to begin. Her baby, already named Nicholas Lee by his anxious parents, was due days ago, and he shows scant signs of being ready to be born. The waiting is all the more tense because the kitchen she waits in is not hers, and the baby she waits for is in another woman's body. Kim Elniskey and her fiance, Jorge Rosario, have chosen Mrs. Weilacker and husband, Paul, to adopt their son, and the two families have gotten to know each other well these past few months, by telephone, letter and now in person as the birth nears.

headline.main: Secrecy and Stigma No Longer Clouding Adoptions

docs.abstract: First of three articles on modern adoptions, In Search of a Child, explores new openness in adoption process; adoption has evolved from secretive, closed process weighed down by dark stigmas and painful misconceptions into infinitely more transparent experience, during which there is open contact between adoptive parents and biological parents; adoption has gone public; increasingly children are told, even before they can fully understand, how they came to their families; loaded phrases such as 'real mother' and 'natural mother' have been replaced by 'birth mother'; researchers are studying how these new, open relationships between birth mothers and adoptive parents are working; there are no complete statistics on how many children are adopted each year, but most recent data, from 1992, show 127,441 children adopted that year, slight increase from five years earlier; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN friends of mine found out they were pregnant, their thoughts turned to iron supplements and Baby Gap. Mine turned to real estate. For two years, my husband, Edward Wyatt, and I lived happily in a one-bedroom fourth-floor walk-up in the East Village, shopping at the health food markets, tripping cheerfully over angry young white girls begging for quarters on St. Marks Place and eating our way through every French bistro and falafel stand in Alphabet City.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer article describes sometimes desperate hunt for new Manhattan apartment after she became pregnant and landlord of her fourth-floor East Village walkup asked her and husband to leave so rent could be raised; list of average Manhattan rents by neighborhood; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: By midweek -- with the World Series gone and the Super Bowl still a distant dream -- sports-crazy men will be vulnerable to painful withdrawal, so it would be nice to have something to keep their minds occupied. Like, say, being present when their wives have a baby. Matt Glickman wishes he had timed his daughter's birth to coincide with a sports doldrum -- she was born during the Final Four, so he had to miss part of that spectacle. That's why the 32-year-old C.E.O. of a baby-products and information company called Baby Center created a ''sports conflict'' page for his Web site. There, dads planning to initiate conception can figure out when to do it with the ''Conception Blocker.'' Just select from 92 different sporting events -- from the Stanley Cup to the Bass Masters Classic -- and then click a button that says, ''When should we not make babies?''

headline.main: At Play in The Conception Zone

docs.abstract: Baby Center chief executive Matt Glickman has created 'sports conflict' Web page to help sports fans plan pregnancies so that deliveries will not conflict with key sporting events (M)
